rawDocs.text:
With that a joyous fellowship 
                    
                      iissued
                      issued

Of 
                  
                    misnterls
                    minstrels
                   making goodly merriment
With wanton bardes and Rhymers impudent
The word remind us that if the great Elizabethan
house, Penshurst or Wilton looks to us out of proportion,

; too a derelict among 
            
              th
              the
             bungalows, it is because the
connection between it and the village is lost. If we could
see the house as it was in Spensers time we should see
tracks raying out from the great house across the fields to
the cottage, to the farm, even to the hovel. War connected
them. Armour, if the enemy came was stored in the church.
The young men practised the great English art of

the long bow. Also there was the other fight, the 
                  pertual
                  perpetual
fight with nature. They must together plough and sow if the
winter were not to starve them. This connection is
between master and man is painfully and minutely recorded
in the medieval letters. It is the staple of the whole
correspondence. But there was also the other less
visible connection--the common belief. That bond between
the different houses has been grown over, like the
track along which the pilgrims rode to Canterbury. No one
rides that way

drives there now. But 
                
                  whe
                  when
                 Spenser came to Penshurst that
track led from house to house. It led to the village green.
It led to the tree; to the well. In the spring they danced
round the Maypole; at midsumer they lit the bon fire on the
hill; at Christmas the mummers acted their dumb show;
the boys came wassailing and were given their
at Harvest time the God was worshipped in the
sheaf of corn; how the May tree was the God was in the

ay
                  bay
                 tree--how in the dances and songs that 
                
                  childre
                  children
                 sing
the old Gods were worshipped, and served. In these dressings

up at the gree midsummer, at Christmas the 
                
                  En lish
                  English
                 
                
                  rememberig
                  remembering
the Gods who were there when the stones were set on end
at Amesbury, at Stonehenge, celebrated their gods; and

at the same 
                
                  tiem
                  time
                 gave shape to to the desire to cease, for

that one day, from the 
                
                  pertual
                  perpetual
                 fight; to be free; to be som

tjing
                  something
                ; to act in their own persons the inner joy; to make

something which had no reason, no use. The 
                
                  schloars
                  scholars
                 tell us

that though 
                
                  t e e
                  the
                 actors, presumably because they slipped

from the common task, and often made mock of it, were 
                
                  despsed
                  despised
despised, yet the great had so much of the common desire

in them that Kings and Queens must have their 
                
                  minstresl
                  minstrels
                , 
                
                  ther
                  their
dancers and singers. Even the Church, conscious as the

preists
                  priests
                 were that it was not 
                
                  theirGod
                  their God
                 but some pagan

wh
                  who
                 was thus 
                
                  hinoured
                  honoured
                , could not suppress the minstrels and
and the rhyners, the mummers, the jugglers, the bear leaders

who came into the village, vho even acted 
                  t eir
                  their
parts in the churchyard.

This was the other 
                
                  bo d
                  bond
                 between the great house

and the cottage. In the noble, as in the 
                
                  pe asnt
                  peasant
                , a half

conscious, anonymous voice 
                
                  mur ured
                  murmured
                 of. The well and the

tree were still 
                
                  hanuted
                  haunted
                ; Some 
                
                  o d
                  old
                 woman in her hovel

was still to the King even the vessel of an unclean 
                spi it
                spirit
              .

She 
                
                  mowed
                  mewed
                 and mobbed and plucked her chin. When the

pilliwinks were 
                
                  appied
                  applied
                 to her, she confessed how she had

how she sailed in a 
                
                  sive
                  sieve
                 singing to the 
                  
                    idle
                    Isle
                   of 
                  
                    undy
                    Lundy

she confessed to how she had 
                
                  throw
                  thrown
                 a cat into the sea and

rasied
                  raised
                 a storm that had sunk the kings ships.
